question: A 49-year-old woman has poorly controlled atrial fibrillation. She suffers a 'stroke' and dies. answers.option: Ischemia lasting more than 10 minutes results in irreversible injury
Irreversible injury initially occurs immediately adjacent to the occluded coronary artery
Coagulative necrosis is more important than apoptosis
Loss of contractility occurs within 60 seconds
ATP is reduced to 50% normal in 30 minutes

question: A 63-year-old woman with complains of a sudden onset of pain in the chest radiating to the back. She has a past history of poorly controlled hypertension. On physical examination: heart rate. 90 beats/minute. respirations 20 /minute, temperature 36.8°C. and blood pressure 150/100 mm Hg. No murmurs are audible. A chest radiograph reveals a widened mediastinum. Laboratory findings: total serum creatine kinase of 55 U/L creatinine 0.9 mg/dL, and glucose 123 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following functions is not carried out by the endothelial cells?
Which of the following is not a feature of an atheromatous plaque?

answers.option: Greater involvement of the abdominal aorta than the thoracic aorta
Eccentric lesions rather than circumferential lesions

question: A 45-year-old man is rushed to the hospital following the sudden onset of an episode of crushing substernal chest pain. He develops cardiogenic shock and receives advanced life support measures. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows chances consistent with a large transmural anterolateral infarction involving the wall of the left ventricle. Which of the following microscopic findings is most likely to be present in this area 4 days following the onset of his chest pain?

A 78-year-old woman has had increasing dyspnea for the past 5 years. On examination, her blood pressure is 130/85 mm Hg. Her BMI is 35 kg/m2. Rales are auscultated in both lungs. Her B-type natriuretic peptide, C-reactive protein, and LDL cholesterol levels are elevated. A chest x-ray shows infiltrates in all lung fields and an enlarged heart. Echocardiography shows decreased ejection fraction with segmental wall motion abnormalities. Which of the following forms of cardiomyopathy is she most likely to have?

A 50-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a sudden onset of substernal chest pain. The pain persists for the next three hours. He then becomes breathless and diaphoretic. On physical examination: temperature 37°C, pulse 100/minute, respiratory rate 26/minute, and blood pressure 130/90 mm Hg. A chest x-ray shows a slightly enlarged heart and mild pulmonary edema. An electrocardiogram (EKG) shows ST segment elevation in anterior leads V1-6. Which of the following serum laboratory test findings is most likely to be present in this man?

A 44-year-old woman dies as a consequence of a 'stroke'. At autopsy, she is found to have a large right basal ganglia hemorrhage. She has an enlarged 550 gm heart with predominantly left ventricular hypertrophy. Her kidneys are small, about 80 gm each, with cortical scarring, and microscopically they demonstrate small renal arterioles that have luminal narrowing from concentric intimal thickening. Which of the following is the most likely condition associated with her findings?

On examination, he is afebrile. A chest radiograph shows cardiomegaly with prominent left and right heart borders, along with pulmonary edema. Laboratory studies show Na⁺ 139 mmol/L. K⁺ 4.3 mmol/L. CI- 99 mmol/L, CO2 25 mmol/L, urea nitrogen 18 mg/dL, creatinine 1.3 mg/dL, and glucose 200 mg/dL. Which of the following additional laboratory test findings is he most likely to have?

answers.option: Hemoglobin of 10.7 g/dL with MCV of 72 fL
Spherocytes on his peripheral blood smear

Angiography reveals a thrombosis of the anterior interventricular (left anterior descending) coronary artery. A 60-year-old patient presents to the clinic with crushing chest pain radiating to the left arm. He is given sublingual nitroglycerin but it does not improve his condition. If the pain lasts for >20 minutes it is more likely to be which of the following conditions?
A patient presents to the clinic with chest pain and is diagnosed with angina pectoris. Which of the following cells sustain the initial injury due to angina pectoris resulting from arterial disease?
What are the right ventricular changes seen in acute cor pulmonale?

A 53-year-old obese male comes to the clinic with complaints of recurrent chest pain. He has experienced similar chest pains for the past few years. He also experiences cramps while walking. His blood glucose level is 170 mg/dl and his cholesterol level is 358 mg/dl. His ECG and cardiac markers are normal. What is the underlying pathology of this condition?
A child is found to have a defect at the limbus of foramen ovale during an annual checkup. What can be the possible structure involved?

A 25-year-old woman presents to the clinic with shortness of breath, swollen feet, and fatigue. An echocardiogram demonstrates a dilated right ventricle and a normal left ventricle. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
Which of the following is infrequently classified as acute coronary syndrome (ACS)?
A patient with pneumonia, who has been bedridden for a long time, has developed swelling in his left leg which hurts to move. What is the most likely diagnosis?

A young male presents to the outpatient department with swelling in his legs and scrotum. On physical examination, his inguinal lymph nodes are enlarged and tender. Which of the following organisms is most likely to be responsible for the patient's condition?

A 5-year-old child is brought to the OPD with a complaint of fever and sore throat. On examination, the child has a swollen neck and a greyish-white membrane in the throat. The most appropriate treatment for this patient is:

A 43-year-old male hypertensive and diabetic for 20 years was diagnosed with atherosclerosis. The atherosclerotic plaque was in one of his coronary arteries due to which he was experiencing chest pain on mild exertion. The key features of atherosclerotic plaques are:

answers.option: A fibrous cap of lipids with internal core of inflammatory cells
Smooth muscle cell migration into the adventitia
A fibrous cap of extracellular and intracellular lipids with endothelial cell
A core of lipids with fibrous cap consisting of smooth muscle cells and collagen

question: A 75-year-old male died as a complication of malignant hypertension. A biopsy from the transverse section of his kidney arterioles was done. Which one of the following histological findings may be found in this case?

answers.option: Homogenous pink hyaline thickening of arterioles
Onion skin concentric thickening with fibrinoid deposits in vessel walls

question: A 67-year-old man had a cough with shortness of breath. His physical examination revealed poorly audible breath sounds and dullness to percussion on both lung bases. He has pedal edema and elevated jugular venous pressure. A diagnosis of cor pulmonale was made. What is the likely cause of cor pulmonale in this case?

A 60-year-old man with a long-standing history of uncontrolled hypertension presents to the emergency with shortness of breath and fatigue. An echocardiogram records the thickening of the left ventricular wall. What is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's cardiac hypertrophy?
What is the most common cause of cystic medial degeneration of the aorta in patients older than 50 years of age?
Which one of the cardiac tumors commonly undergoes regression?
Which of the following types of vasculitis is mediated by immune complex deposition?

A 55-year-old man with a history of smoking and high cholesterol presents with chest pain during exertion that is relieved by rest. His blood pressure is elevated, and his doctor suspects a blockage in his coronary arteries. Which of the following conditions is most likely responsible for his symptoms?

A 67-year-old man had a cough with shortness of breath. His physical examination revealed poorly audible breath sounds and dullness to percussion at both lung bases. He has pitting edema to his feet and elevated jugular venous pressure. A diagnosis of cor pulmonale was made. What is the most likely cause of cor pulmonale in this case?
Which of the following is a key morphological feature of Hypertensive Heart Disease?

answers.option: Formation of fibrotic plaques in the coronary arteries
Atrophy of the left ventricle with thinning of the ventricular wall
Increased size of the left atrium with no changes to the ventricles
Right ventricular hypertrophy with tricuspid valve regurgitation
Left ventricular hypertrophy with increased wall thickness

question: Which of the following symptoms is most commonly associated with inferior wall myocardial infarction?

answers.option: Dizziness and palpitations with a sharp pain radiating to the jaw
Severe chest pain radiating to the left arm, accompanied by coughing
Sharp chest pain worsened by breathing, often relieved by sitting forward
Sudden onset of shortness of breath and sweating without chest pain

question: Which of the following best describes the underlying cause of atherosclerosis?

answers.option: Infection of the blood vessels, leading to inflammation and swelling
Narrowing of veins due to dehydration and decreased blood volume
Narrowing of the arteries due to excessive calcium buildup, which occurs rapidly in young individuals
Accumulation of fatty deposits, cholesterol, and other substances in the arterial walls, leading to plaque formation
Weakening of arterial walls, resulting in aneurysms and ruptures

question: Atherosclerosis is a slowly progressive disease of large and medium-sized muscular arteries and is characterized by:

answers.option: Embolization, high blood pressure, and endothelial dysfunction
Endothelial dysfunction, vascular inflammation, and the buildup of lipids in vessel
Altered blood flow with stasis, and development of fatty streak in vessel wall
Hardening of arteries due to high blood pressure

question: A 6-year-old boy is brought with the complaint of fever and pain in the left knee joints for the past 2 days. Since yesterday, the pain in the left knee joint has improved but now the left and right ankle joints are painful. ESR is raised. Which of the following is required to fulfill the diagnostic criteria for this patient's most likely illness?
